Long_definition: It is characterised by white spot on cornea, pricking pain and vision loss. It is explained by increased vali (nagan and koorman) and Aẕal( aalosaga Aẕal). Among the seven udalthathukkal saram, seneer, Ūṉ, Koẕuppu, Eṉpu and Mūḷai gets affected

Short_definition: Corneal eye disease with scorpion like structure in cornea
Long_definition: It is characterised by scorpion like structure in cornea. It is due to heat and lacrimation stagnation of the eyes. It is explained by increased vali (nagan and koorman). Among the seven udalthathukkal saram gets affected .

Short_definition: Corneal ulcers with pain and irritation in eyes
Long_definition: It is characterised by corneal ulcers with pain and irritation in eyes. It is due to heat in the eyes, lacrimation stagnation of the eyes. It is explained by increased vali (nagan and koorman) and Aẕal( aalosaga Aẕal). Among seven udalthathukkal saram g

Short_definition: Corneal eye disease with dew like appearance on the cornea which causes vision loss
Long_definition: It is characterised by dew like appearance on the cornea which causes vision loss. It is due to heat in the eyes, lacrimation stagnation of the eyes. It is explained by increased vali (nagan and koorman) and Aẕal( aalosaga Aẕal). Among seven udalthathuk

It is characterised by lacyrmation. It is due to heat in the eyes, stagnation of excessive watery discharge in the eyes. It is explained by increased vali (nagan and koorman), Aẕal( aalosaga Aẕal) and iyam (tharpagam). Among the seven udalthathukkal sara

It is characterised by indistinct small letters and words are confounded, headache. It is explained by increased vali (nagan and koorman) and Aẕal( aalosaga Aẕal). Among seven udalthathukkal saram, seneer, Ūṉ, Koẕuppu, Eṉpu and Mūḷai gets affected

Short_definition: Corneal eye disease with vision loss during evening
Long_definition: It is characterised by vision loss during evening. It is explained by increased Aẕal( aalosaga Aẕal). Among the seven udalthathukkal saram, seneer, Ūṉ, Koẕuppu, Eṉpu and Mūḷai gets affected

Short_definition: Corneal eye disease with increased lacrimation, rhinitis and blurred vision
Long_definition: It is characterised by increased lacrimation,rhinitis, pricking pain in both sides of the eye and blurred vision. It is explained by increasedAẕal( aalosaga Aẕal) and iyam (tharpagam). Among the seven udalthathukkal saram, seneer, Ūṉ, Koẕuppu, Eṉpu and M

Short_definition: Corneal eye disease with decreased vision
Long_definition: It is characterised by decreased vision and increased lacrimation. It is explained by increased Aẕal( aalosaga Aẕal) and iyam (tharpagam). Among the seven udalthathukkal saram and seneer gets affected.

Short_definition: Corneal eye disease with pain, blurry vision and bluish discoloration of cornea
Long_definition: It is characterised by pain in the pupil, blurry vision, bluish discoloration of cornea and clear lacrimation. It is explained by increased vali (nagan and koorman) and Aẕal( aalosaga Aẕal). Among the seven udalthathukkal saram and seneer gets affected

Short_definition: Corneal eye disease with blurred and cloudy vision during sunset
Long_definition: It is characterised by blurred and cloudy vision during sunset. It is due to intake of bitter and sour food substances and constipation. It is explained by increased Aẕal( aalosaga Aẕal). Among the seven udalthathukkal saram, seneer, Ūṉ, Koẕuppu, Eṉpu

Short_definition: Corneal eye disease with fleshy growth in the cornea and heaviness of the eyelid
Long_definition: It is characterised by fleshy growth in the cornea , heaviness of the eyelid, lacrimation, prickng pain in forehead, photophobia and foggy vision. It is explained by increased vali (nagan and koorman), Aẕal( aalosaga Aẕal) and iyam (tharpagam). Among the

Short_definition: Corneal eye disease with heaviness of eyelids and headache
Long_definition: It is characterised by heaviness and pricking pain of eyelids, swelling of lateral canthi of eye, bluish discoloration of pupil and headache. It is explained by increased vali (nagan and koorman) and Aẕal( aalosaga Aẕal). Among the seven udalthathukkal

Short_definition: Corneal eye disease with increased lacrimation
Long_definition: It is characterised by increased lacrimation, diminished vision and swelling of lower eyelid. It is explained by increased Aẕal ( aalosaga Aẕal) and iyam (tharpagam). Among seven udalthathukkal saram, seneer, Ūṉ, Koẕuppu, Eṉpu and Mūḷai gets affected.

Short_definition: Corneal eye disease eith fleshy tissue growth over the cornea
Long_definition: It is characterised by fleshy tissue growth over the cornea, photophobia, heat, lacrimation, mucus discharge and pain in the occipital and vertex region. It is explained by increased vali (nagan and koorman), Aẕal( aalosaga Aẕal) and iyam (tharpagam) . In

Short_definition: Corneal eye disease with white thickening of the cornea with blurred vision
Long_definition: It is characterised by white thickening of the cornea with blurred vision. It is explained by increased vali (nagan and koorman) and Aẕal( aalosaga Aẕal).among seven udalthathukkal saram gets affected

Short_definition: Corneal eye disease with vascularised thickening of the conjuctiva pterigium
Long_definition: It is characterised by vascularised thickening of the conjuctiva pterigium . It is explained by increased vali (nagan and koorman) and Aẕal( aalosaga Aẕal). Among the seven udalthathukkal saram and seneer gets affected

Short_definition: Corneal eye disease due to increased pitham and drug allergy
Long_definition: It is characterised by increased Aẕal and drug allergy. It is explained by increased Aẕal( aalosaga Aẕal). Among the seven udalthathukkal saram and seneer gets affected.

Short_definition: Corneal eye disease with fleshy growth over the cornea and in flammation of the eye
Long_definition: It is characterised by fleshy growth over the cornea and inflammation of the eye. It is explained by increased vali (nagan and koorman) and Aẕal( aalosaga Aẕal). Among the seven udalthathukkal saram, seneer, Ūṉ, Koẕuppu, Eṉpu and Mūḷai gets affected.

Short_definition: Scleral disease of the eye classified under vali

Long_definition: It is characterised by fleshy growth in the sclera. It is explained by increased Aẕal( aalosaga Aẕal). Among the seven udalthathukkal saram, seneer, Ūṉ, Koẕuppu, Eṉpu and Mūḷai gets affected

Short_definition: Tissue growth in the sclera with inflammation
Long_definition: It is characterised by tissue growth in the sclera with inflammation. It is explained by increased vali (nagan and koorman) and Aẕal( aalosaga Aẕal). Among the seven udalthathukkal saram, seneer, Ūṉ, Koẕuppu, Eṉpu and Mūḷai gets affected

It is characterised by fleshy growth in the sclera resembling the shape of black dhal (Phasea mungo). It is explained by increased vali (nagan and koorman) and Aẕal( aalosaga Aẕal). Among the seven udalthathukkal saram, seneer, Ūṉ, Koẕuppu, Eṉpu and Mūḷa

Short_definition: Fibrovascular growth covering the sclera of the eye
Long_definition: It is characterised by fibrovascular growth covering the sclera of the eye. It is explained by increased vali (nagan and koorman) and Aẕal( aalosaga Aẕal). Among the seven udalthathukkal saram, seneer, Ūṉ, Koẕuppu, Eṉpu and Mūḷai gets affected

Short_definition: Inflammatory vascular congesion of the sclera
Long_definition: It is characterised by inflammatory vascular congesion of the sclera. It is explained by increased vali (nagan and koorman) and Aẕal( aalosaga Aẕal). Among the seven udalthathukkal saram and seneer gets affected

It is characterised by bluish discolouration in the sclera with irregular surface. It is explained by increased vali (nagan and koorman) and Aẕal( aalosaga Aẕal). Among seven udalthathukkal seneer gets decreased

Short_definition: Scleral disease of the eye classified under azhal
Unclear vision due to memrane covering
Long_definition: It is characterised by unclear vision due to membrane covering in to the sclera. It is explained by increased vali (nagan and koorman) and Aẕal( aalosaga Aẕal). Among the seven udalthathukkal saram, seneer, Ūṉ, Koẕuppu, Eṉpu and Mūḷai gets affected
It is characterised by episcleral vascular congesion. It is explained by increased Aẕal( aalosaga Aẕal). Among the seven udalthathukkal saram and seneer gets affected.
It is characterised by haemorrhagic blister of the sclera. It is explained by increased Aẕal( aalosaga Aẕal). Among the seven udalthathukkal saram and seneer gets affected.

Short_definition: Scleral disease of the eye classified under aiyam
Tissue growth in the sclera with watery discharge
Long_definition: It is characterised by tissue growth in the sclera with lacrimation. It is explained by increased vali (nagan and koorman) and Aẕal( aalosaga Aẕal). Among the seven udalthathukkal saram and seneer gets affected.
It is characterised by abscess in the sclera. It is explained by increased iyam (tharpagam). Among the seven udalthathukkal saram, seneer and Ūṉ gets affected

Short_definition: Memrane covering the white part of the eye
Long_definition: It is characterised by thickened membrane covering the white part of the eye. It is explained by increased vali (nagan and koorman) and Aẕal( aalosaga Aẕal). Among the seven udalthathukkal saram, seneer, Ūṉ, Koẕuppu, Eṉpu and Mūḷai gets affected

It is characterised by episcleral vascular congestion. It is explained by increased vali (nagan and koorman) and Aẕal( aalosaga Aẕal). Among the seven udalthathukkal saram, seneer, Ūṉ, Koẕuppu, Eṉpu and Mūḷai gets affected

It is characterised by watery blisters in the sclera. It is explained by increased vali (nagan and koorman) and Aẕal( aalosaga Aẕal). Among the seven udalthathukkal saram, seneer, Ūṉ, Koẕuppu, Eṉpu and Mūḷai gets affected

Short_definition: Lackish tissue growth in the sclera
Long_definition: It is characterised by blackish tissue growth in the sclera. It is explained by increased vali (nagan and koorman) and Aẕal( aalosaga Aẕal). Among the seven udalthathukkal saram, seneer, Ūṉ, Koẕuppu, Eṉpu and Mūḷai gets affected

Short_definition: Sclera appears like the scales of fish
Long_definition: It is characterised by appearance of sclera like scales of fish. It is explained by increased vali (nagan and koorman) and Aẕal( aalosaga Aẕal). Among the seven udalthathukkal saram, seneer, Ūṉ, Koẕuppu, Eṉpu and Mūḷai gets affected
A power endowed by nature to every individual for self preservation which regulates its normal functions. It is the administrator, protector and healer of the body.
The temperament of an individual in different phases of life.
urine that denotes the excess of immature phlegm
urine that contains emulsified fat derived from tissues
urine that contains phlegm from the actual or threatened dissolution of tissues
urine when mixed with pus indicates the ulceration of urinary tract and without pus indicates the presence of partially matured phlegm or stone in the bladder
urine that passes during crisis of phlegmatic swellings, in case where the tissues are loose and in the diseases caused by vitreous phlegm
urine, which is a grave sign when passes without sediment
urine, which is a fatal sign when passed in the course of an acute fever

Short_definition: urine like colour of raw-meat washings
Long_definition: urine, which denotes weakness of liver or excess of blood

Short_definition: urine like colour of olive oil
Long_definition: clear, viscid and moderately dense urine, in which the yellow colour is tinged with oily translucence. It gives an oily sheen and indicates bad prognosis
urine that points towards fatal prognosis as it is an indication of the combustion of yellow and black bile
The temperament of human being which is considered to be the most perfect and noble in comparison with all other species. This temperament is inclined towards heat.

A type of temperament caused by the predominance of Dam (sanguine) in the body. It is hot and moist. The individuals with this type of temperament have strong built, full pulse, pinkish colour of skin, etc.

A type of temperament caused by the predominance of Balgham (phlegm) in the body. It is cold and moist. The individuals with this type of temperament have fatty body, excessive sleep, whitish colour of skin, etc.

A type of temperament caused by the predominance of Ṣafrā’ (yellow bile) in the body. It is hot and dry. The individuals with this type of temperament have thin built, yellowish colour of the skin, rapid pulse, etc.

A type of temperament caused by the predominance of Sawdā’ (black bile) in the body. It is cold and dry. The individuals with this type of temperament have thin built with prominent veins, blackish color of the skin, etc.
urine in which red colour is tinged with the black colour and is a sign of any complicated fever or fever occurring due to thick humour
urine which generally shows that maturation is incomplete and sometimes indicates towards obstruction in the blood vessels or weakness of kidneys
urine which generally shows defective maturation  and sometimes indicates towards elimination of thick mature humours
urine indicative of cold morbid temperament, excessive rawness and extinction of innate heat in case of acute diseases
urine indicative of predominance of yellow bile. Foul sour smelling urine is indicative of predominance of black bile
froth of urine, which denotes jaundice
froth of urine, which denotes jaundice
smallness of urine bubbles
urine bubbles, which denote viscidity of matter
lack of urine bubbles

sanguine humour, devoid of  its normal qualities either through change of temperament such as getting hot or cold or due to admixture with the humours derived from outside or produced within the sanguine humour, e.g., when a part of it gets putrefied, the lighter portion is converted into abnormal yellow bile and the heavier portion into abnormal black bile

Short_definition: excess of  bubbles/ froth  in urine
Long_definition: abundance of urine bubbles which denotes viscidity of matter and presence of gas
bursting of urine bubbles in a slow manner which indicates viscidity of matter and presence of gas
rapid bursting of urine bubbles
large red or large white sediments, usually coming from the organs of urinary system. White flaky sediments come from the bladder and red or fleshy flaky sediments come from the kidney

Short_definition: flaky sediments like husk of grain
Long_definition: small and thick scales denoting bladder disorder or wasting of organs
reddish small and thick scales denoting the destruction of liver substance or combustion of blood. Occasionally they come from kidneys
scales which are produced due to burning of blood

Short_definition: flaky sediments resembling coarse particles of barley
Long_definition: scales when reddish denote burning of blood. Dark scales show excessive destruction of blood
flat and large white or red scales which generally arise from the immediate urinary organs, e.g., kidneys, bladder
sediments, which arise from kidneys or from the breakdown of tissues in the body
phlegm devoid of basic characters of normal phlegm
one of the abnormal types of phlegm, which is saline or alkaline in taste and inclined towards heat and dryness
one of the abnormal types of phlegm, having foul smell, produced by sepsis/infection/putrefaction
one of the abnormal types of phlegm, which is sour in taste and inclined towards coldness and dryness
one of the abnormal types of phlegm, which is tasteless, very immature and quite cold
one of the abnormal types of phlegm, which is gallic in taste and inclined towards coldness and dryness
one of the abnormal types of phlegm, which is sweet in taste and inclined towards heat and moistness
one of the abnormal types of phlegm, having  watery consistency
one of the abnormal types of phlegm, having extremely thick consistency
one of the abnormal types of phlegm, having mucoid consistency
one of the abnormal types of phlegm, having vitreous consistency
sediments, which generally denote dissolution of solid and liquid fat as well as flesh
sediments, which denote discharge of pus from ulcers of urinary organs
sediments, which generally denote presence of large quantity of thick immature humour in the body

Short_definition: sediments like a wet piece of leaven
Long_definition: sediments, which denote weakness of stomach and intestine and impairment of digestion
sediments, which generally denote weakness of liver when found in large quantity and ulceration or injury of the urinary tract when found in small quantity
sediments, which indicate that active heat has coagulated the elongated exudates and converted them into fibrils
sediments, which indicate stone formation or stone disintegration
sediments, which denote the change in the colour of pus or mucus due to their prolonged stagnation
a term denoting the abundance of sediments in urine due to excess of causative agent
a term denoting the scantiness of sediments in urine due to lack of causative agent
yellow bile that becomes abnormal either due to addition of  extraneous material or alteration in its own composition
one of the abnormal types of yellow bile, produced by the admixture of thick phlegm
one of the abnormal types of yellow bile, produced by the admixture of thin phlegm
one of the abnormal types of yellow bile, produced by the admixture of burnt black bile

one of the abnormal types of yellow bile, produced by the combustion of ordinary yellow bile, resulting in development of leek green colour due to mixing of the burnt material  with the original yellow bile
the hottest and the most lethal of all abnormal types of yellow bile produced due to extreme combustion of leek green bile
sediments, which denote excessive burning of blood, excessive cold or failure of innate heat
sediments, which denote the predominance of sanguine or impaired digestion
sediments, which denote the presence of strong heat or insidious disease
sediments, which indicate the appearance of dark coloured sediments in urine
sediments, which may be normal or abnormal (purulent, mucoid and gummy denoting deficient maturation)
quantity of stool, which denotes presence of excessive humours in the body
quantity of stool, which denotes the presence of low quantity of humours in the body or the retention of much of stool in the caecum, colon and small intestine
consistency of stool, which denotes indigestion, obstructions, weakness of the mesentery and catarrhal secretions coming from head
black bile produced either by the combustion of black bile itself or combustion of any of the other three humours, i.e., sanguine, phlegm, yellow bile
one of the abnormal types of black bile, produced by the combustion  of sanguine
one of the abnormal types of black bile, produced by the combustion  of yellow bile
one of the abnormal types of black bile, produced by the combustion  of phlegm
one of the abnormal types of black bile, produced by the combustion  of black bile itself
consistency of stool, which denotes  fatigue, excessive urination, presence of excessive heat in the body, use of dry foods and constipation
colour of stool, which denotes excess of yellow bile in the body
colour of stool, which denotes obstruction in the bile duct and jaundice
colour of stool, which denotes excessive combustion, maturation of causative matter of melancholic diseases or intake of any coloured diet
colour of stool, which denotes extinction of the innate heat
shape of stool, which denotes flatulence
passing out of stool before the usual time, which denotes the excess of bile in gall bladder and weakness of retentive faculty
delay in the passage of stools, which denotes weakness of digestion, coldness of intestines and excess of moisture
sputum that denotes predominance of yellow bile and severity of heat
sputum that denotes predominance of sanguine
single disease  is produced either due to the abnormality of temperament or composition or breach in continuity
sputum that denotes predominance of sanguine and heat
sputum that denotes coldness, immaturity and heat
sputum that denotes the combustion and bad quality of disease causing matter
sputum, which denotes that the disease causing matter is still in an immature state
sputum denoting the thickness of disease causing matter
sputum denoting the severity of putrefaction
sputum denoting good prognosis
profuse expectoration, which denotes the maturity of disease causing matter and stationary phase of disease
scanty expectoration, which denotes the progressive phase of disease
moderate expectoration, which denotes the convalescence

Short_definition: abnormal temperament/morbid temperament/ impaired temperament/immoderate temperament
Long_definition: temperament wherein the qualities and quantities of all the participating primary components in a compound are not in accordance with the natural needs

RegionalTerm: مزاج غیر معتدل مفرد/سوء مزاج مفرد
Long_definition: imbalance of  temperament occurring due to dominance of any one of the four qualities, i.e., heat, cold, dryness, moistness, on the other three qualities

Term: Sū’-i-Mizāj Mufrad Sāda/Mizāj Ghayr Mu‘tadil Mufrad Sāda
RegionalTerm: سوء مزاج مفرد سادہ/مزاج غیر معتدل مفرد سادہ
Long_definition: when derangement of temperament is without any substance
when the heat dominates abnormally in the body
when the cold dominates abnormally in the body
when the wetness dominates abnormally in the body
when dryness dominates abnormally in the body
a simple abnormal temperament which is associated with the substance
abnormal hot temperament caused by the predominance of hot substance
abnormal cold temperament caused by the predominance of cold substance
abnormal wet temperament caused by the predominance of wet substance
abnormal wet temperament caused by the predominance of dry substance

RegionalTerm: مزاج غیر معتدل مرکب/سوء مزاج مرکب
Long_definition: imbalance of  temperament occurring due to dominance of any two of the four qualities, i.e., heat, cold, dryness, moistness

Term: Sū’-i-Mizāj Murakkab Sāda/Mizāj Ghayr Mu‘tadil Murakkab Sāda
RegionalTerm: سوء مزاج مرکب سادہ/مزاج غیر معتدل مرکب سادہ
Long_definition: the compound abnormal temperament which occurs when any two (one active and one passive) of the four physical properties i.e. hotness, coldness, dryness and wetness/moistness dominate abnormally on the other without involving the substance

Short_definition: simple  hot and wet abnormal temperament
Long_definition: abnormal predominance of hot and wet temperament without involving the substance

Short_definition: simple hot and dry abnormal temperament
Long_definition: abnormal hot and dry temperament caused by only predominance of hot and dry temperament without involving the substance

Short_definition: simple cold and wet abnormal temperament
Long_definition: abnormal cold and wet temperament caused by only predominance of cold and wet temperament without involving the substance

Short_definition: simple cold and dry abnormal temperament
Long_definition: abnormal cold and dry temperament caused by only predominance of cold and dry temperament without involving the substance

Short_definition: compound abnormal temperament associated with substance
Long_definition: compound abnormal temperament which occurs when any two (one active and one passive) of the four physical properties i.e. hot, cold, dry and moist dominate abnormally on the other due to predominance of substance

Short_definition: abnormal hot and wet temperament associated with substance
Long_definition: abnormal hot and wet temperament associated with predominance of hot and wet substances

Short_definition: abnormal hot and dry temperament associated with substance
Long_definition: abnormal hot and dry temperament associated with predominance of hot and dry substances

Short_definition: abnormal cold and wet temperament associated with substance
Long_definition: abnormal cold and wet  temperament associated with predominance of cold and wet substances

Short_definition: abnormal cold and dry temperament associated with substance
Long_definition: abnormal cold and dry temperament associated with predominance of cold and dry substances
sweat that denotes predominance of yellow bile in the body
sweat that denotes predominance of sanguine in the body
sweat that denotes predominance of black bile in the body
sweat that denotes predominance of black bile in the body
sweat that denotes predominance of black bile in the body
sweat that denotes healthy condition of  the body
condition that denotes weakness and decreased vitality
condition that denotes the weakness of repulsive faculty
condition that denotes severity of putrefaction and heat
condition that denotes presence of bilious, pungent and sharp matter
the temperament which comes into being when any one of the four physical properties i.e. hotness, coldness, dryness and wetness/moistness dominates abnormally on the other three
sweat that denotes sour phlegm
condition that denotes the thinness of disease causing matter
condition that denotes the thickness of disease causing matter

one of the four groups of causes of health and disease whose immediate subject is the organs and their pneuma, the more remote subject is the humours and the most remote subject is the primary components

one of the four groups of causes of health and disease which either preserves or produces changes in the human body and are: (a) various types of airs and associated factors; (b) food, water and other drinks, etc.; (c) evacuation and retention; (d) habitat and residence, etc.; (e) physiological and psychological rest and activity; (f) sleep and wakefulness; (g) various phases of life and variations therein; (h) sex variations; (i) occupations; (j) habits; and (k) favourable and unfavourable agents  affecting the human body by contact
one of the four groups of causes of health and disease  which includes temperaments, faculties emerging from these temperaments and structures
one of the four groups of causes of health and diseases, which includes functions
the causes which are common to many diseases
abnormal temperament wherein the change in four qualities, i.e.,  hotness, coldness, dryness and wetness/moistness is associated with increase/decrease of substance (humour)
causes which are specifically responsible for creating pathological lesion/ disease
causes related to body itself
two causes occur at the same time for a disease and absence of either of these result in the end of the disease. e.g. sepsis in fevers
causes that befall the body from within (repletion, starvation)

Short_definition: causes that befall the body from outside (trauma, cold, heat)
Long_definition: non-corporeal (out side the body) causes which produce corporeal states directly e.g. blow, atmospheric heat, hot or cold food or psychological factors like anger or fear
essential causes  usually intrinsic in nature
the causes that are dependant on other causes

Short_definition: the causes when abolished, their effects persist
the causes when abolished, their effects disappear

Long_definition: the causes which are not basic in nature but arise out of certain basic causes
The essential factors in association with the structure and functions of the body i.e. Arkān, Mizāj, Akhlāṭ, A‘ḍā’, Arwāḥ, Quwā and Af‘āl. Each of them is must to sustain the body.
Simple bodies which are primary substances of human and non-human bodies. They can not be subdivided into bodies which have different forms. Their intermixture results in different forms in nature.

One of the four primary substances found in nature, bearing the natural properties of heat and dryness. The role it plays in the construction of things is to mature, refine and intermingle with all things.

One of the four primary substances found in nature, bearing the natural properties of heat and moisture. Its effect and value in (the world of) creation is to rarefy and render things finer, lighter, more delicate, softer and better able to move to the lighter spheres. Sometimes, this term is also used for the gases arising from different organs in their pathological state.

One of the four primary substances found in nature, bearing the natural properties of cold and moistness. Its purpose in (the world of) creation lies in the fact that it lends itself readily to dispersion and consequently assumes any non-permanent shape.

One of the four primary substances found in nature bearing the natural properties of cold and dryness. Its purpose in the (world of) creation is to fix and hold the being together into a compacted form

A quality that is produced by action and reaction of opposite qualities of elements which are broken up in small particles in order to facilitate their mixing. When these components interact among themselves, a condition is produced, which is found in equal proportion in all the particles of the compound.
The temperament in which the hot and dry physical properties dominate the other two physical properties i.e. cold and moist.
The temperament in which the hot and moist physical properties dominate the other two physical properties i.e. cold and dry.
The temperament in which the cold and dry physical properties dominate the other two physical properties i.e. hot and moist.
The temperament in which the cold and moist properties dominate on the other two physical properties i.e. hot and dry
The fluids of the body that serve the functions of nutrition, growth and repair of the organs.
One of the four basic humours, red in color bearing hot and wet temperament. It is excellent among all the humours.
One of the four basic humours which is white in colour and bears cold and wet temperament. It is next to sanguine humour in excellence
One of the four basic humours. It is yellow in colour and has hot and dry temperament. It is next to phlegm in excellence.
One of the four basic humours. It is black coloured and has cold and dry temperament.
A light gaseous substance found in organs and fluids of the body and performs various important functions. It is obtained from the interaction of inspired air with Akhlāṭ Laṭīfa.
The Rūḥ (pneuma) which is found in the organs of psychic faculty and its centre is brain.
The Rūḥ (pneuma) which is found in the organs of vital faculty and its centre is heart.
The Rūḥ (pneuma) which is found in the organs of natural faculty and its centre is liver.
The solid parts of the body which are derived primarily from the coarse humours. These are the essential tools to accomplish vivid functions.
The organs in which the visible and perceptible parts carry the same name and definitions as the whole organ e.g. flesh, nerve, etc.
The organs in which the comprising parts irrespective of size differ in nature as well as name for the whole organ.
A natural and specialized ability of the body for the performance of its specific function.
The natural and specialized power which is furnished in an individual for digestion and assimilation of food and evacuation of waste from the body.
The power which is furnished in an individual for the intellectual, sensory and motor function of the body.
The power which is furnished in an individual to receive other powers essential for the survival.
The natural and specialized powers which are furnished in an individual for preservation of its species.
The bodily activity essential for fulfilling the objectives of the body. It is performed by the organs and also testimony to the presence of powers in them.
The functions which are vital for the survival. These are performed by Quwā Ḥaywāniyya and executed by A‘ḍā’ Ḥaywāniyya.
The functions that are performed by the psychic faculty of the body. These are performed by Quwā Nafsāniyya and executed by A‘ḍā’ Nafsāniyya.
The functions which are essential to energize all the powers and develop the organs. These are performed by Quwā Ṭabī‘iyya and executed by A‘ḍā’ Ṭabī‘iyya.

Short_definition: stable abnormal temperament or constant intemperament
Long_definition: abnormal temperament, which continues in a steady mode and does not get corrected easily

Short_definition: the causes that distort the shape of the organ

Long_definition: the causes that are responsible for obstruction, it may be inflammation/swelling of the tract or presence of any foreign body
the causes that are responsible for narrowing of the tract, it may be inflammation/ swelling of the tract or presence of any foreign body
the causes that are responsible for dilatation of the tract may be weakening of the circular constricting fibres, increased eliminating power or drugs that dilate the tract temporarily
the causes that are responsible for roughness of the surface include the use of detergent, resolvent, dry or cold medicines, etc.

the causes that are responsible for smoothness of the surface of the skin or mucous membrane include the use of demulcent substance, mild resolvent medicine, mild hot medicine that normalizes the coldness of the surface

the causes that are responsible for dislocation or displacement of the organs, includie increased tension/ pressure in the joint, rigorous movement or any condition that loosens the joint/ muscle etc.

Short_definition: causes of abnormal association between organs
Long_definition: the causes that are responsible for abnormal association such as stiffness, spasm, flaccidity of the adjacent organ or foreign body affecting the organ in contact
the causes that are responsible for abnormal movement of an organ such as weakness, dryness, spasm or collection of morbid material in the organ

Short_definition: causes of increase in size of organ
Long_definition: the causes responsible for increase in size include increased quantity of material due to increased absorption in the organ
abnormal temperament, which does not continue in a steady mode and gets corrected easily

Short_definition: causes of increase in number of organ
Long_definition: the causes responsible for increase in number which is usually due to malformation

Short_definition: causes of decrease in size of organ
Long_definition: the causes that are responsible for decrease in  size of organ due to malformation, accidental loss or decaying by infection etc.

Short_definition: causes of decrease in size and number of organ
Long_definition: the causes that are responsible for decrease in number of organ may be malformation, accidental loss or decaying by infection

Short_definition: factors modifying the state of human body
causes of loss of continuity of the organs
Long_definition: causes of loss of continuity of organ include internal causes like, corrosive humour (as caseation and loss of tissue in leprosy) or excessive abnormal humour (accumulated in joints in arthritis) or may be due to external causes, that may include injury by sharp object, too hot object or heavy object etc.
causes of ulcer formation  may be bursting of inflammatory mass, pustule or abscess, pus formation in an injury, etc.

causes of inflammation may be strong expulsive power of adjacent organ and weak retentive power of the affected organ. The causes of inflammation of organ may vary depending upon nature of the organ, texture of the organ, width of the passage or orifice which may be too narrow or too wide related to the organ, low position of outlet and small outlet, and increased heat in particular regions
causes of pain include sudden and temporary change in temperament or loss of continuity
causes that relieve the pain, include the removal of the cause of pain or increase in the moistness, inducing sleep, use of soothing and analgesic agents
causes of pleasure including sudden restoration of abnormal temperament and restoration of loss of continuity
diseases in which original shape of the organ is changed
one of the types of diseases of constitution involving particularly the morphological alterations in the compound organs
one of the types of diseases of constitution specific to tracts/ tubular structures such as vessels, ducts etc. In these conditions the lumen may get dilated, narrowed or completely blocked
dilatation of tracts/ ducts
narrowing of tracts/ ducts
obstruction of tracts/ ducts
one of the types of diseases of constitution seen in hollow organs leading to either abnormal narrowing or dilatations. It includes increase, decrease, occlusion or emptiness
dilatation of vasa/cavity
narrowing of vasa/cavity
vasa/ cavity getting obstructed or repleted, e.g. obstruction of ventricles of brain in apoplexy
depletion of vasa/cavity

Short_definition: diseases of surface of the organs
Long_definition: one of the types of diseases of constitution associated with the alterations in surface  of viscera/organ causing compromised physiological functions e.g. a viscera originally having smooth surface becomes rough/puckered and vice versa
roughness of the surface which should be smooth, e.g. roughness of internal surface of trachea
smoothness of the surface which should be rough, e.g. smoothness of internal surface of stomach
one of the types of diseases of constitution that deal with the pathological changes in size / weight of body viscera/organs. All kind of hypertrophies or atrophies come under this category
increase in the size, e.g. elephantiasis
generalized/ as a whole increase in the size, e.g. obesity
localized increase in the size/increase in the size of part/organ of the body, e.g. hepatomegaly, splenomegaly etc.
decrease in the size of the organs
generalized/ as a whole decrease in the size, e.g. emaciation
localized decrease in the size/ decrease in the size of part of the body, e.g. shrinkage of the size of the eyeball or tongue

Short_definition: diseases affecting the numbers of organ of the body
Long_definition: one of the types of diseases of constitution which is associated with the congenital or acquired numeral abnormality of viscera or body organs
increase in number of the body parts, like appearance of extra teeth and fingers

Short_definition: congenital increase in number of parts of the body
Long_definition: congenital increase in number of parts of the body, e.g. additional teeth or additional finger

Short_definition: acquired pathological increase in the parts of the body
Long_definition: acquired pathological increase in the parts of the body, e.g. tumour
decrease in number of the body parts, e.g. presence of one kidney instead of two

Short_definition: congenital decrease in number of organs
Long_definition: congenital decrease in number of body parts, e.g. congenital absence of one finger

Short_definition: acquired decrease in number of organs
Long_definition: acquired decrease in number of parts of the body, e.g. accidental loss of one finger

one of the types of diseases of constitution in which defects in position and proximity of body organs occur. The defects in position include total or partial shifting of any organ. It also includes the defects in voluntary and involuntary movements of body organs. The movement may decrease or increase. The defects in proximity include, loss of gap between two adjacent organs leading to cessation of their movement

Short_definition: the diseases related with the position
Long_definition: there are four types of diseases related to the position: 1. total shifting of the organ from its position, 2. partial shifting of the organ like in hernia, 3. involuntary abnormal increased movement of an organ like in tremors and 4. decreased movement of a movable organ like stiffness of joint
complete displacement of body part, like displacement of joint. When the head of the bone completely subluxate from its normal position
incomplete displacement or displacement of part of an organ, like intestinal hernia
abnormal (sometimes involuntary) movement of an organ, like tremors
fixity of an organ to its location, like calcification of joints in gout
the disease of an organ that arises due to its association with another organ
restriction of movement of an organ, which was movable
painful movement or difficult movement

weak expulsive faculty, strong retentive faculty which may result due to weakness of digestive faculty,  narrowing  and obstruction of passages and thickness, viscidity and increased amount of waste material

strong expulsive faculty, weak retentive faculty, matters causing injury by its excess quantity which produces heaviness, gaseous substances, distension, corrosive and acrid matters, dilution of matters and extended passage

these include weakness of digestive faculty, weak evacuation power, strong retentive power, narrowing of ducts and channels, Ḥammām (Turkish bath/bath) after meal,  excess of repose and lack of exercise and movement

causes of weakness of organs may include persistent abnormal temperament especially cold abnormal temperament, weakness of texture of the organ especially of nerves, weakness of different faculties and presence of compound disease etc.

factors of life including air, foods and drinks,  bodily movement and repose, mental activity and repose, sleep and wakefulness,  retention and evacuation which are essential for every living human being; and an imbalance in these factors lead to various disease conditions
treatment of diseases by manipulating and maintaining the dietary pattern depending upon the requirement of treatment of diseases
complete abstinence from the intake of food temporarily to facilitate the evacuation of morbid matter from the body commonly in the treatment of acute illnesses
reducing/ lessening the intake of diet in order to conserve the power of digestive faculty

Short_definition: reducing/ lessening the dietary intake quantitatively
Long_definition: reducing/ lessening the quantity of dietary intake but maintaining the nutritional requirement of the body

Short_definition: reducing/ lessening the dietary intake qualitatively
Long_definition: the quantity of diet in terms of nutritional value is reduced which decreases the production of humours and provides favourable medium for concoction of morbid matters
loss of continuity of any organ or part of the body
loss of continuity of skin caused by sharp pointed object
loss of continuity of vein
sudden break in the continuity of a body part
loss of continuity of skin due to excoriation/ scraping
loss of continuity of bone in such a way that it breaks into pieces
longitudinal loss of continuity of bone
longitudinal minimal loss of continuity of nerve
longitudinal loss of continuity of muscle
transverse loss of continuity of nerve
loss of continuity of muscle at its end
transverse loss of continuity of muscle

RegionalTerm: تقلیل غذا ءبہ اعتبار کمیت و کیفیت
Short_definition: reducing/ lessening the dietary intake qualitatively as well as quantitatively
Long_definition: the diet both in terms of quality and quantity is reduced particularly when faculties of body are not markedly disturbed
it is the treatment of disease with the help of medicines/ drugs
treatment of disease with single medicines e.g. herbal, mineral or animal origin
treatment of disease with compound drugs/ formulations e.g. tablets, syrups, powders and other semisolid dosage forms

one of the basic principles of treatment in Unani system of medicine in which the physician chooses the drugs, diets or any other mode of treatment having qualities opposite to the quality/temperament of the disease

Short_definition: treatment of patients with psychiatric/spiritual measures
principle of treatment of correction of an abnormal temperament that leads to morbidity
the process of making the morbid matter/ humour easily evacuable
Long_definition: a process by which the morbid material matures and is made evacuable out of body. The drugs for Nuḍj(concoction) or the duration of Nuḍj(concoction) is specific to humoral morbidity
the process by which the humours mature and is made evacuable from the body
the process by which the phlegm humour matures and is made evacuable from the body
when any humour exceeds the normal quantity

Short_definition: diseases due to predominance of sanguine humour either qualitative or quantitative
Long_definition: the diseases which arise due to the abnormal quantity or quality of the sanguine humour. These diseases are considered to be of hot and moist temperament

Short_definition: diseases due to predominance of bilious humour either qualitative or quantitative
Long_definition: the diseases which arise due to the abnormal quantity or quality of the bilious humour. These diseases are considered to be of hot and dry temperament

Short_definition: diseases due to predominance of phlegmatic humour either qualitative or quantitative
Long_definition: the diseases which arise due to the abnormal quantity or quality of the phlegmatic humour. These diseases are considered to be of cold and moist temperament

Short_definition: diseases due to predominance of melancholic humour either qualitative or quantitative
Long_definition: the diseases which arise due to the abnormal quantity or quality of the melancholic humour. These diseases are considered to be of cold and moist temperament

Quantitative increase in volume of Dam exerting pressure on the vessels that may lead to heaviness in the body in general and eyes, head and temporal region in particular and may also lead to bleeding due to rupture of delicate vessels

Qualitative imperfection or quantitative excess of Ṣafrā’ in the body characterized by rapid and swift pulse, urine that is flame yellow and of thin consistency, increased thirst, dryness and roughness of tongue and bitter taste, yellowish discolouration of skin and eyes,  etc.

Qualitative imperfection or quantitative excess of Balgham in the body characterized by sluggishness, soft skin, excessive secretion of sticky saliva, delayed digestion, increase in sleep, slow pulse, etc.

Qualitative imperfection or uantitative excess of Sawdā’ characterized by rough, dry and dark skin, increased appetite, increased viscosity of blood, dark coloured/blackish urine, tendency to develop splenic diseases and psychiatric disorders
the process by which yellow bile matures and is made evacuable from the body
the process by which Black bile matures and is made evacuable from the body

Short_definition: evacuation of morbid matter/ humours from the body
Long_definition: induced evacuation of morbid matter/ humours from the body

Short_definition: elimination of morbid matter/ humour from the body
Long_definition: induced elimination of morbid material from the body, usually done after proper concoction

Short_definition: elimination of morbid matter/ humour from the brain
elimination of morbid matter/ humour from the head
elimination of morbid matter/ humour from the chest
elimination of morbid matter/ humour from the teeth
elimination of morbid matter/ humour from the stomach
elimination of morbid matter/ humour from the liver

Long_definition: pulse, the parts of which are perceived to be greater in length when compared with absolutely normal pulse

Short_definition: elimination of morbid matter/ humour from the spleen
elimination of morbid matter/ humour from the intestine
elimination of morbid matter/ humour from the kidney
elimination of morbid matter/ humour from the urinary passage

Long_definition: principle of treatment of removal of pus from ulcers through drugs

Short_definition: elimination of morbid matter/ humour from the body of lactating mother
diverting/ attracting the morbid matter/ humour
Long_definition: diversion of morbid matter/ humour from the affected site to another site or increase in the flow of humours towards a specific site

Short_definition: diverting/ attracting the morbid matter/ humour towards an adjacent organ/ part of the body
Long_definition: diversion of morbid humours from the affected site towards the adjacent organs or parts of the body

Short_definition: diverting/ attracting the morbid matter/ humour towards distant organ/part of the body
Long_definition: diversion of morbid matter/ humour from the affected site towards a distant organ or part of the body

Short_definition: to induce pain by any mean
Long_definition: the process to induce pain by any means like pressing or tying the organ or cupping of the organ, etc. performed to divert the morbid matter
pulse, the parts of which are perceived to be shorter in length when compared with absolutely normal pulse
to shift the morbid material from diseased part to distant non vital part
to bring morbid materials at normal/balanced condition
to bring blood at normal consistency
the process to bring yellow bile to its normal condition
moderation of temperament or bringing the abnormal temperament to the normal temperament
removal of the cause of the disease or treatment of the cause

Short_definition: to stop the infiltration or effusion of the humours
Long_definition: to stop the infiltration or effusion of the humours from one organ to another

Short_definition: warming/to produce heat in the body/ part of the body
Long_definition: a method of treatment in which the heat is produced/ generated within the body by drugs or regimens
pulse, the parts of which are perceived to be broader in breadth when compared with absolutely normal pulse

Short_definition: producing warmth in case of  predominance of cold morbid temperament
Long_definition: a method of treatment in which the heat is produced/ generated within the body by drugs or regimens

Short_definition: producing heat in the cardiac end of the stomach
producing heat in the urinary bladder

Long_definition: pulse, the parts of which are perceived to be narrower in breadth when compared with absolutely normal pulse

Short_definition: producing heat in the semen producing organs

Long_definition: principle of treatment in which extremities are warmed through various means to divert the disease causing matter from the affected organs towards them

Short_definition: increasing the room temperature of patient
Long_definition: principle of treatment advocated in case of cold morbid temperament

Short_definition: cooling of the body/part of the body
Long_definition: a method of treatment in which coldness is produced/ generated or heat is reduced within the body by drugs or regimen

Short_definition: producing cold in case of  predominance of hot morbid temperament
Long_definition: a method of treatment in which the cold is produced/ generated within the body by drugs or regimens

Short_definition: producing cold in the cardiac end of stomach

Long_definition: pulse, the parts of which are perceived to be more elevated in height when compared with absolutely normal pulse

Short_definition: decreasing the room temperature of patient
Long_definition: principle of treatment advocated in case of hot morbid temperament

Short_definition: moistening of the body or the part of the body
Long_definition: the process of moistening of the body or the part of the body by drugs or regimen

Short_definition: producing moistness in case of  predominance of dry morbid temperament
Long_definition: a method of treatment in which the moistness is produced/ generated within the body by drugs or regimens
The state of health in which the structure and functions of the body are in normal state.
pulse, the parts of which are perceived to be less elevated in height when compared with absolutely normal pulse

Short_definition: producing moisture in the room of patient
the process of reducing the heat
Long_definition: the process of reducing the increased heat of the humours and organs

Short_definition: removing the vapours accumulated in an organ or body part
inducing dryness in the body or the part of the body
Long_definition: the process of producing dryness in the body or the part of the body

Short_definition: the process of producing dryness by absorbing the fluid from any part of the body
Long_definition: the process of producing dryness through absorption of fluids and other material from the body especially towards intestine as in case of Ishāl (purgation) by the action of drugs
the act of refining of any thick viscid matter

Short_definition: the process of resolving the inflammation

Long_definition: pulse increased both in length and breadth as well as in elevation

Short_definition: the process of softening the inflammation
Long_definition: the process of softening the inflammation of hard organ/ inflammation associated with black bile

Short_definition: to induce rupture of pustular swelling
Long_definition: to induce rupture of an abscess through local application of drugs/regimen
the process of dilatation of the blood vessels either by using drugs having hot and wet temperament or by drugs that dissolve the thick substance blocking  the vessels
the process to remove any obstruction by using deobstruents
elimination of anything which is an addition in quantity or quality to the physiological composition of blood and considered as an impurity, by drug or any regimen
pulse diminished both in length and breadth as well as in elevation

Short_definition: to cut out the morbid matter
Long_definition: cut out the morbid material to make it easily evacuable

Short_definition: making the disease causing matter dilute

Long_definition: attracting the morbid matter from the affected site to another site. It is one of the objectives of Imāla
making the thin morbid matter thick to facilitate its evacuation and prevent from absorption in other organs

Short_definition: adsorption/lubrication of the surface of organ
Long_definition: the process of lubricating the surface of organ, e.g.,  intestine
the process that repels the morbid material from affected part
the process which expels the flatus from the gastrointestinal tract
relaxing the muscles which commonly results in pain reduction
the process which stimulates the nerves
pulse increased both in breadth and height

Short_definition: process which stimulation the functioning of brain
the process of toning up and strengthening of the organs and body
Long_definition: the process of toning up to enhance the functions and maintain the health of the human body by stimulating the metabolism, strengthening the internal organs and improving the body functions
the process that strengthens the vital organs i.e.. heart, brain and liver
the process that strengthens the brain
the process which provides strength to the nerves

Short_definition: toning up and strengthening of the vision
Long_definition: the process which improves the eyesight

Short_definition: toning up of gums and teeth
Long_definition: the process which binds the gums and strengthens the teeth
the process which tones up the heart and improves its function
the process which tones up the liver and improves its function
pulse decreased both in breadth and height
the process which strengthens the kidney and improves its function
the process which strengthens the bladder and improves its function

Short_definition: toning up of the sexual power/ libido
Long_definition: the process which strengthens the genitals and improves its function
the process which strengthens the uterus and improves its function

Short_definition: toning up of the skin to grow hair
Long_definition: the process which strengthens the skin to grow hair
pulse, which resists the fingers of physician during palpation

Short_definition: transforming the morbid humour into moderate consistency
disintegrating the morbid material into smaller particles
transforming the body humours into moderate consistency
advising the diets which produce blood of thin consistency
advising measures, e.g., food, drink, exercise which are light in nature and produce freshness
dispersion of disease causing matter accumulated in an organ or body part
resolving the gases accumulated in an organ or body part

Long_definition: pulse which does not resist the fingers of physician during palpation

Short_definition: dispersion of vapours accumulated in an organ or body part

Long_definition: the process which increases the circulation of blood of the skin and helps in growing of the hair
a method of treatment in which the whole body or a part of it is reversibly anaesthetized through drugs
to induce sleep with the help of the drugs or regimens

Short_definition: (1)  to relieve the pain; (2) to produce the soothing effect; (3) to reduce the peristaltic movements
Long_definition: the term is used for (1) relieving any type of pain; (2) producing soothing effect in any local lesion; (3) causing anti diarrhoeal effect by reducing the peristaltic movement

Short_definition: cooling the increased heat of the body
alleviating the vapours arising from any organ
to cause sedation of the brain
Long_definition: the process that reduces the irritability or excitement of brain

Short_definition: the process of reducing abnormally increased  function of heart

Long_definition: pulse whose movement is completed in a short space of time
to relieve the pain by using drugs, changing temperament of the pain site or by some other means
the process of reducing perspiration/ sweating, required when there is excessive sweating
the process to induce blister formation by hot fluid or by some drugs to increase the blood supply of a particular organ e.g. liniments used in male sexual debility
cleaning of the infected wound with some drugs like blue vitriol
promotion of wound healing by the use of desiccant drugs
the process of increasing production of milk by drugs e.g. seeds of cumin, onion, turnip and fennel seeds etc.
pulse whose movement is completed in a long space of time

Short_definition: to increase the formation of semen
Long_definition: the process of increasing the formation of semen by quality diet and drugs e.g. asphaltum, asparagus racemosus, cotton seeds, salep etc.
the process of increasing the consistency of semen by some drugs/diets
the process by which the ejaculation is delayed by using some drugs to treat premature ejaculation

Short_definition: condensation of vapours accumulated in an organ or body part
to increase the secretion of milk

Long_definition: the process of increasing the urination by some drugs/diets
the process of increasing the menstrual flow in case of amenorrhoea, dysmenorrhoea, etc. through drugs/regimens

Short_definition: the process of crushing the stone
Long_definition: the process of crushing the stone (usually renal/ureteric/vesicular), by some drugs/regimens
the process to kill the intestinal worms by drugs called vermicide/anthelminthic
the process to expel out the intestinal worms by drugs called vermifuge
pulse having small pause between two beats

Short_definition: reducing the production of breast milk

Long_definition: process to check or eradicate the infection
the process to reduce the temperature (of the body), usually achieved by sweating or application of some cooling agents like cold water or by some drugs etc.

Short_definition: reducing the quantity of disease causing matter
reducing the weight of the body or its part
Long_definition: the process to shed the body weight or to reduce the bulk of any part of the body/organ

Short_definition: increasing the weight of the body or its part
Long_definition: the process to increase the body weight or the bulk of any part of the body/organ

Short_definition: softening of content of the intestine
Long_definition: the process to soften the intestinal content or to evacuate the excrement from intestine
regimenal therapy is modification in six essential factors (AAsbāb Sitta Ḍarūriyya), for the maintenance of health as well as for the management of diseases
The intermediate state of the body, in between, the state of health and the state of disease. It is a state of neither health nor disease
pulse having long duration of pause between two beats

Short_definition: evacuation of morbid matter from the body through intestines
Long_definition: evacuation of matter from the body through intestines as a regimen
to induce the vomiting as a regimen to evacuate the gastric contents

Short_definition: to induce increased flow of urine or menstruation
Long_definition: to induce the increased flow of urine or menstruation as a regimen

Short_definition: induced expectoration/ expulsion of sputum from the lungs
Long_definition: the regimen/drugs by which sputum is expelled out/ expectorated from the lungs
blood letting through venesection is one of the mode of regimenal therapy for complete evacuation of morbid matter, leading to moderation of all humours

Short_definition: a mode of regimenal therapy in which horns (now a days cups) are used with or without scarification for diversion and evacuation of morbid matter from the blood.
Long_definition: a mode of regimenal therapy which is used for diversion or evacuation of the morbid matter from the body. It may be  without scarification or with scarification (blood letting). Previously the animal horns had been used but now a days metal/ plastic cups and small suction pump are used on the body surface to create the vacuum through suction for the diversion or evacuation of morbid matter.

Short_definition: cupping therapy with scarification for blood letting
Long_definition: cupping therapy with scarification for blood letting to achieve local evacuation of morbid matter
cupping therapy without scarification, only application of cups with vacuum creation within it for diversion of morbid matter

Short_definition: dry cupping, where vacuum is created with fire  inside the cups
cupping therapy where vacuum is created without fire

Long_definition: easily compressible pulse
cupping therapy along with warm water/ medicinal decoction while cupping
leech application as a regimen is one of the method of evacuation. It is specially useful at the site where venesection or hijamah is not done properly
sweating as a regimen is usually done to remove morbid matter through skin

Short_definition: bath/ turkish bath for therapeutic purpose
Long_definition: turkish bath, which is constructed as per specific guidelines, where the temperature of different rooms are different for therapeutic purpose like cleansing, reducing the viscosity of matter and elimination and diversion of morbid matter

in this type of bath, the person is kept in a high temperature, thus stay in hot and dry room as well as in hot and wet room is prolonged. Beneficial for spasms, pain in liver and kidney, and pain in joints
in this type of bath medicated water is used
in this type of bath a little borax is mixed in the water
in this type of bath a little sulphur is mixed in the water. It is beneficial for different skin diseases etc.
in this type of bath part of the body or whole body up to neck is covered with sand. It is beneficial for ascites, arthritis, and frozen joints etc.
taking bath in sea water, different kind of salts in sea water is beneficial for skin
firm and incompressible pulse
exposure to sunlight is often called sun bath. It is beneficial for different skin diseases and to tan the white skin
in this type of bath some oil or some drugs dissolved in olive oil is massaged over the body
in this type of bath the water is used in which some strong astringent like alum is dissolved

Short_definition: induced physical movement of the body as a regimen
the exercise, which is not intentionally done
Long_definition: the exercise, which is not intentionally done but carried out as a part of profession like that of work of blacksmith

Short_definition: exercise which is purely done intentionally for the particular purpose
Long_definition: exercise which is purely done for the purpose and intentionally in order to get benefits of exercise
exercise for a shorter duration, stopped soon after starting
exercise that is not stopped sooner but continued for a longer duration
extensive/ rigorous exercise, usually done forcefully. This may lead to hardening of the organs, but sometimes may lead to excessive evacuation and lethargy
light exercise, where much force is not used. It may be done by moving from one place to another etc.
pulse which seems to be full of blood
rapid/ fast exercise, where movement is done rapidly at a fast pace
slow exercise, where movement is done at a slow pace
exercise which is done slowly and without much force
moderate exercise, where force as well as movement is moderate

Short_definition: therapeutic massage using multiple techniques from light, moderate to deep pressure
Long_definition: regimen involving manual manipulation of muscles, leading to elimination of metabolic waste
strong and extensive pressure massage in order to harden an organ

Short_definition: soft handed lilght and gentle pressure massage
Long_definition: soft handed light and gentle pressure massage done in order to open up the channels/ vessels leading to softening of the organ
pulse which seems to be empty
massage, moderate in terms of force as well as time leading to healthy organs
rough massage, usually done with any rough cloth, it increases peripheral blood circulation excessively
soft or smooth massage usually done with oil or soft cloth
the massage done before exercise as a preparatory measure
massage done after exercise, to relax the body/ organ and bring back to its normal condition
treatment of diseases through surgical procedures
procedure of burning the skin or flesh to stop bleeding or avoid further putrefaction with the help of heated instrument or caustic substance
procedure of cauterization with heated metals
procedure of cauterization with heated iron
procedure of cauterization with heated gold
pulse having higher temperature
procedure of cauterization with caustic substances
making of cut  into the body during surgical interventions
surgical intervention of the swellings
process of making incision over the abscess to drain the pus
rupture of a swellings
procedure of making a cut into the larynx under the third or the fourth ring of trachea
surgical procedure carried out to remove the  stone from urinary bladder
procedure involving amputation of limbs affected by gangrene
cutting a bone or piece from it
surgical procedure of removal of skin of prepuce
pulse having lower degree of temperature
procedure of removal of twisted veins surgically
procedure to remove ascitic fluid
cutting or removal of the part of the body to control the disease process
art of the setting of the fracture or dislocation
procedure of reduction of dislocated joints of body
surgical procedure, which involves the stitching of the edges of wound with the help of sutures

Short_definition: maintenance of health and management of diseases through diets

Long_definition: dietary substance, which becomes part of the body and does not produce any qualitative change such as heat, cold, etc.
diet, used  without the addition of other substances
diet prepared by the combination of many other substances
pulse equal in its five features, i.e., largeness and smallness, strength and weakness, swiftness and sluggishness, rapidness and slowness and hardness and softness
dietary substance, which produces heat in the body
dietary substance, which produces cold in the body
dietary substance, which produces wetness in the body
dietary substance, which produces dryness in the body
dietary substance producing healthy effect in the body
dietary substance producing unhealthy effect in the body

Short_definition: diet with potential of becoming the part of organ
Long_definition: diet, which has potential to become the part of body organ

Short_definition: diet with potential of becoming the part of organ after the action of innate heat
Long_definition: dietary substance, which has potential to become the part of body organ after getting affected by the innate heat of body

Short_definition: diet ready to become part of organ
Long_definition: dietary substance, which is ready to become part of body organ such as secondary fluid
dietary substance, which departs from its specific form and becomes the part of the body organ

Short_definition: pulse equal in its five features
Long_definition: pulse equal in largeness and smallness, strength and weakness, swiftness and sluggishness, rapidness and slowness and hardness and softness
substance, which is primarily used as diet but produces some pharmacological actions

Short_definition: diet affecting through matter, quality and specific form

dietary substance, which spontaneously does not get absorbed in the organs and a considerable amount of residue is left behind in the stomach and vessels

dietary substance, which is not digested completely

dietary substance, providing little nourishment
